Hello team,

Sometimes we face some issues where there are many lines on a single comment and this become very painful to scroll it down until the next comment, specially if this is in a middle of the thread.

My suggestion is to implement something similar as Microsoft Outlook 2010 (see image below), which has quick shortcuts for next/previous conversations at the start of a conversation.
!http://www.howtogeek.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/image185.png!

I believe that it will save a lot of time for JIRA users. :)

Thanks!

fields.description:
The original issue is marked as "resolved" (https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-24558) but the problem still exists. There should be an option for "lower case usernames" in the embedded Crowd in Jira. This is especially needed when migrating from an internal user directory to LDAP where the usernames are the same but LDAP usernames can have capital letters.

*Steps to reproduce*
# Create a user with username "administrator"
# Login with username "administrator" and create a ticket A
# Configure a LDAP connector
# Inside the LDAP directory, create a username "Administrator"
# Make the LDAP directory at the top of the User Directories
# Create another ticket B
# Issue Navigator can only search for ticket B

There are also other errors like the user cannot see own issues, dashboard etc.

This error happens because JIRA is using the column *user_name* in the table *cwd_user* for all operations. JIRA should have used the column *lower_user_name*. For example, the table *jiraissue* is showing "Administrator" in the column *reporter* for ticket B.
fields.summary: JIRA using mixed-case username from LDAP

fields.description:
User without any group membership appear in the Assignee Field.

Steps to reproduce:
# create a new group called "testgroup"
# create a user called "vicky" in the Internal Directory. Associate the user to group "testgroup"
# in the Permission Scheme, associate the group "testgroup" to the Assignable User permission.
# create a new issue and try to assign it to the user "vicky". Issue can be assigned to "vicky".
# create the Internal with LDAP Authentication directory
# create a new user called "vicky" in the delegated directory. This user not member of group "testgroup"
# arrange the directory sequence so that the delegated directory on top
# in the user list, user "vicky" from the delegated group will not have the group "testgroup"
# create a new issue. Then, try to assign to the user "vicky". Vicky is listed in the Assignee field. But, it will throw error that "vicky" can not be assigned.


From the test, it's seems that the Assignee field is retrieving the user "vicky" from the internal directory instead of the delegated directory.
fields.summary: User Without Group Membership In Delegated LDAP listed in the Assignee Field

fields.description:
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-29044 happens otherwise.

For example, search for "greenhopper feedback" on JAC. You'll get an empty set of results because JIRA will think you're looking for "project = GHS AND issuetype = feedback" what you really want is "project = GHS and text ~ feedback"

Fixing this would involve giving the project name/key priority over the issue type if the text people are searching for happens to match an issue type. Alternatively we could go for ordered fields; "greenhopper feedback" would result in "project = GHS and text ~ feedback" but "feedback greenhopper" would result in "issuetype = feedback and text ~ greenhopper".
fields.summary: JIRA smart search should only match issue types that are in the identified project

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29038].
  {panel}

As a subcontractor for DirecTV, we interact with JIRA many times per day.  Here are some suggestions for improvements, which are supported by DirecTV:

1. It's annoying that sub-tasks can't have sub-tasks.  Sub-tasks of sub-tasks should be allowed.  Further, there should be a list in tasks (and sub-tasks) showing what sub-tasks they have.

2. When email goes to jirahddvr@directv.com, with a recognizable ticket in the subject, JIRA forwards the email to the assignee for the ticket.  Helpfully, it checks to see if the assignee is the same as the sender of the email, and in that case, it does not forward the email.  It should also check the Cc: list of the email to see if the assignee is on the list, and in that case it should also not forward the email.

3. JIRA believes that two issues can be linked as "is related to", "is related by", "duplicates", or "is duplicated by".  There is no semantic difference between "is related to" and "is related by" because "is related to" is a symmetric relation (and so is "duplicates").  JIRA should get rid of "is related by" and "is duplicated by".                                       -- George
fields.summary: Subtasks need subtasks; related/duplicated should be symmetric; less email

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When editing an issue that doesn't have a priority indicated, the selected priority in the list is not the default priority from the priority scheme.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set the default priority to critical
# Create a new project 
# Configure the field configuration to hide the "Priority" field
# Create a ticket which uses the modified field configuration
# Re-add the priority field to the field configuration (Show)
# Edit the ticket
# Look for the priority field

h3. Expected Results
The selected priority in the list is the default priority from the priority scheme.

h3. Actual Results
The selected priority in the list is *not* the default priority from the priority scheme, instead it is simply the first option in the list.

h3. Notes
This is actually happening because hiding the Priority field from the field configuration will cause issues to be created without a value in "Priority". When an issue that does not have a priority is edited, the priority selected by default on the list will always be the top option.

h3. Workaround
Do not hide the Priority system field in the Field Configuration.
fields.summary: Edited Issues That Previously Doesn't Have Priority Won't Select The Default Priorities as The First Value

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29029].
  {panel}

I have the following two use cases and especially the activity log and activity stream are giving me a hard time right now:

o I use custom listeners to copy estimates into linked issues and copy comments into parent issues
o I use workflow transitions that transition to the same status to execute post functions (e.g. copy an issue to another project)

Whenever I use any one of those, I end up with a lot of unuseful entries showing up in the activity stream, e.g.

o The original comment + another entry for the copied comment
o Messages that User A opened a ticket (actually he transitioned the issue from Open to Open)
o and so on

What I really need is the ability to change how these changes are represented in the activity log / stream and / or prevent them from showing up at all.
fields.summary: Ability to change / prevent what shows in activity log / stream

{noformat}

h5. To Replicate

This can be replicated multiple ways across products - please see CWD-2854 & CONF-25646 for further information.

h5. Workaround

# Schedule a downtime window, as users will be unable to login during these changes.
# Log in as an administrator within the JIRA Internal Directory. [If one does not exist, create it|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Retrieving+the+JIRA+Administrator#RetrievingtheJIRAAdministrator-IfnousersorgroupsexistinJIRA].
# Disable the problematic User Directory.
# Create a new [User Directory|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+User+Directories] within JIRA, using the same settings as the old one.
# Test the synchronisation and ensure that synchronisation completes successfully. If so, use this new directory.

(!) If you have a User Directory set up with the Read Only, with Local Groups [permission settings|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+to+an+LDAP+Directory#ConnectingtoanLDAPDirectory-PermissionSettings] you will no longer have the local groups set up in the database when the user directory is disabled. The project roles will not be affected.

If you are using Microsoft AD, you can try to use the [adsiedit.msc|http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc773354(v=ws.10).aspx] to change the SAMAccountName attribute for the users to lowercase in the LDAP.
fields.summary: Mixed case usernames breaks the connection between JIRA and LDAP for User Management

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29011].
  {panel}

Customers use GApps to log in and also to manage users in JIRA.
Before the licensing change it was possible to just remove the users from the groups and they would be removed from groups in JIRA and so freeing up licenses again.
Licensing is now managed by application access, which is not changed if users are taken out of groups.
Ideally the new feature would revoke application access when you remove users out of groups in GApps and so automatically free up licenses without the need for the administrator to log in and make the changes manually.
fields.summary: Revoke application access when users are disabled in GApps

With the German language, search string with hyphen( - ) and contains(~)gives all issue contains either stringA OR stringB and  stringA-stringB  if the JQL is entered "*summary ~ stringA-stringB*"

Step to reproduce:

Create three issues just as follows:
||key||summary
|TP-1|Test an easycredit Issue 1 textB text
|TP-2|text easycredit mein 2 textB testA
|TP-3|mein-easycredit 3 textA-textB text-easycredit

Run 3 different search-query in the issue navigator:
* SEARCH 1: {code}summary ~ textA-textB{code}
* SEARCH 2: {code}summary ~ text-easycredit{code}
* SEARCH 3: {code}summary ~ mein-easycredit{code}

SEARCH 1 and SEARCH 2 return the expected results.

However, SEARCH 3 returns all the three issues which is unexpected where it should only return "*TP-3: mein-easycredit 3 textA-textB text-easycredit*"


Screenshot attached.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-28986].
  {panel}

This new feature was added to the User Directories, as in the attached screenshot. Unfortunately we don't seem to have any documentation on it and it's a bit confusing about what the functionality does and does not do.

So far, based from the case I worked on and JRA-24213 it seems to be able to:
* Migrate *all users* from JIRA Internal to Delegated LDAP.
* Migrate *all users* from Delegated LDAP to JIRA Internal.
* Migrate *all users* from Delegated LDAP to Delegated LDAP.

It does not support (requested in JRA-27868):

* Migrating a specific set of users from one directory to another.
* "Connector" User Directories - so direct to the LDAP Server (e.g.: Active Directory).
* Migrating groups only.

It seems to have the following features:
* If you, the currently logged in user, are in the directory to be migrated from, your user data will not be migrated.
* Users and groups will not be migrated if they already exist in the target directory. For example, if {{dcurrie}} exists in JIRA Internal and JIRA Delegated LDAP, yet has different groups in JIRA Internal, when migrating from one to the other, that user will be skipped an the groups will not be migrated.

And of note:
* Project Roles are not affected as they do not seem to be user directory specific (unlike groups).

This originally derived from JRA-24213 and now has a subsequent issue to add more functionality to the feature, JRA-27868.

Can you please add some documentation for this feature? (it came in as part of 5.0.3 and somehow missed the [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/JIRA+5.0.3+Release+Notes]).

Thank you!
fields.summary: Please add some documentation for the 'Migrate users from one directory to another' Functionality

fields.description:
To fix issues in inline edit for JIRA 5.1, the jira.webresources:viewissue resource was separated into:

- jira.webresources:viewissue-components, and
- jira.webresources:viewissue

viewissue-components is always pulled in, but viewissue is only pulled in if inline edit is disabled. This is an incorrect naming as https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/Loading+Issue+Tab+Panels+with+AJAX#LoadingIssueTabPanelswithAJAX-UsesofWebResourceManager.requireResource%28java.lang.String%29 tells plugin devs to explicitly pull in jira.webresources:viewissue.

Proposed solution:
- rename viewissue to viewissue-no-inlineedit (this only includes 2 resources that are overridden in kickass)
- rename viewissue-components to viewissue
- alias viewissue-components as viewissue (as it's been in released in 5.1 and at least one plugin has been fixed to reference viewissue-components)
fields.summary: jira.webresources:viewissue incorrectly separated for JIRA 5.1

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-28980].
  {panel}

When attempting to invoke the SOAP procedure 'getIssue', no XML response is received for some issues, resulting in an exception when using Python's SOAPpy and a NULL return value when using Perl's SOAP::Lite.

The problematic issues were identified using the attached SOAPtest.py and SOAPtest.log.

An investigation has determined that all of the issues for which this error occurs contain non-printable characters (in this case, 0xBD, 0xBF, 0xEF).

The characters were most likely introduced inadvertently when text was copied from an e-mail or RTF/Word document.

JIRA should be capable of either (a) stripping out bad characters when text is entered, or (b) correctly stripping or escaping bad characters when generating a SOAP response.

Note that that aggregate-issue SOAP methods (e.g. getIssuesFromJqlSearch, getIssuesFromTextSearchWithLimit) also fail when any issue in which the above problem exists would be included in the returned issue collection.
fields.summary: SOAP: cannot retrieve issue details when non-printable chars present in text fields

fields.description:
We had a SAC outage last night and this was due to the HistoryFieldValueValidator trying to find all possible values for the status field on SAC.

This means it runs a query through the ChangeItem table for the field 'status'.  In the code we use a DefaultOfBizListIterator (great) but then call getCompleteList() on it which loads *everything* from the result set into memory.  This caused an OOME since on SAC there's ~2.2 million rows for the status field in the change item table (with 4 GB of heap).

fields.description:
See the attachment !MSIE_Workaround_Text.png|thumbnail! ...

This text implies that the workaround mode is only applied when the user's browser is MSIE.  While part of the code that enforces it does indeed check the browser's user agent, JRA-20915 and JRA-28331 changed the enforcement of it such that the wiki renderer is instructed not to inline embedded objects at all, regardless of the browser setting, when in "workaround" mode.

Based on conversations with several people, this change in behaviour is entirely intentional, so we need to update the descriptions for this setting (as well as any related documentation) so it is clear what the enforcement does and that it applies to all browsers.

Actual behaviour in 5.0.6+:
* Secure - No embedded content is rendered, whether it's an image or an "object" (flash, quicktime, sounds, etc.)
* Insecure - All content is rendered.
* Workaround - Embedded images are rendered, but "objects" are not.
fields.summary: Help text for MSIE workaround is confusing / inaccurate since 5.0.6

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-28958].
  {panel}

I understand that there are certain error conditions that JIRA can't really recover from. However, some are common enough that you should be able to catch and display a properly formatted message to the user. Our database server went down recently—and while we are tracking down the cause for it, JIRA should have handled the situation better. There are two different behaviors for a downed database, depending on whether JIRA was running at the time or not.

If JIRA was already running when the database goes down:

We get a stack trace of your code with a final exception saying it can't connect to the database.

If JIRA is also shut down, but started before the database is ready:

JIRA writes it's .lock file
We get a generic Tomcat Error screen with no information, no stacktrace, nothing.
When you shut the JIRA service back down, the .lock file remains

What I would like to see, at least for when the database is down:

A similar page to the case when there is an existing .lock file, but this time telling the user that the database can't be connected to.
Proper cleanup of the .lock file when the service is shut down.
fields.summary: Provide a better error page if you cannot connect to the database.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-28953].
  {panel}

It will be great if JIRA have the feature to WARN users if it is running on an unsupported platform/environment. Perhaps the warn message can be appended to the logs file, and users will immediately spot the problem upon checking the logs and fix the issue themselves. 

Sample use case:
- Currently JDK 1.7 is not supported by JIRA 
- If we have the application running with JDK 1.7, a lot of exceptions will be thrown during JIRA startup (e.g.: bundled plugin failed to load, etc)
- Hence, having the feature to warn users that JDK 1.7 (instead of throwing loads of exceptions) during startup may be a good idea
fields.summary: Add the ability to have JIRA warn the users if the application is running on an unsupported environment
